name: Bologna
fun_fact: Fun fact: Bologna has THREE nicknames - 'La Grassa' (the fat one) for being Italy's food capital, 'La Dotta' (the learned) for Europe's oldest university (founded 1088), and 'La Rossa' (the red) for its terracotta rooftops AND historic communist politics!

hero_dishes.name: Tagliatelle al Rag√π
hero_dishes.description: Hand-rolled fresh egg pasta ribbons with slow-cooked meat sauce (the REAL bolognese)
hero_dishes.origin_story: This is THE place to eat hand-rolled fresh pasta with complex, meat-laden rag√π. NEVER order 'spaghetti bolognese' here - it doesn't exist! The authentic version uses tagliatelle (never spaghetti) with a slow-cooked sauce of multiple meats. Bologna is where this world-famous sauce was born.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Trattoria Anna Maria (signature dish), Da Cesari (family-run since 1955), Trattoria da Me (romantic family-run since 1937), CasaMerl√≤ (bold pop interior mixing classics with modern), Sfoglia Rina (excellent traditional lunch value)

hero_dishes.name: Tortellini in Brodo
hero_dishes.description: Tiny hat-shaped pasta stuffed with pork, prosciutto, mortadella, Parmigiano Reggiano, nutmeg, and egg, floating in rich beef and poultry broth
hero_dishes.origin_story: Both Modena and Bologna claim to have invented this traditional dish, but they agree on one thing: the hat-like shape was inspired by the Goddess Venus' navel! The filling is specific and sacred - pork, prosciutto, mortadella, Parmigiano, nutmeg, egg. One of the world's best soups.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Sfoglia Rina (one of the best traditional lunch values in Bologna, perfect for satisfying tortellini cravings), traditional trattorias throughout the historic center

hero_dishes.name: Lasagne Verde
hero_dishes.description: Green spinach pasta layered with rag√π bolognese, b√©chamel, and Parmigiano Reggiano
hero_dishes.origin_story: Bologna's version of lasagna uses green spinach pasta sheets, distinguishing it from versions elsewhere in Italy. The layers of handmade pasta, slow-cooked rag√π, and creamy b√©chamel represent La Grassa at its finest.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional trattorias and osterias throughout Bologna - a must-order alongside tagliatelle al rag√π

hero_dishes.name: Mortadella
hero_dishes.description: Bologna's famous cured pork sausage with cubes of fat and pistachios, protected under PGI status
hero_dishes.origin_story: Sometimes called 'Bologna' in English, this is the REAL thing in its birthplace. Bolognese cuisine heavily relies on pork meat - mortadella is the crown jewel of the city's salumi tradition.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Osteria del Sole (historic institution since 1465, BYO food - they pour the wine), served as antipasto at traditional restaurants, sold at local markets

signature_drinks.name: Lambrusco
signature_drinks.description: Sparkling red wine from Emilia-Romagna, slightly sweet and effervescent
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: The region's famous sparkling red wine serves to 'de-grease the palate' from all the rich food! Pairs perfectly with mortadella, rag√π, and other heavy Bolognese dishes. Don't be snobby about it - locals know it's the perfect match for La Grassa cuisine.

signature_drinks.name: Pignoletto
signature_drinks.description: Sparkling white wine from nearby vineyards
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: A lighter alternative to Lambrusco, enjoyed as an aperitivo or with lighter pasta dishes

food_culture_notes: NEVER order 'spaghetti bolognese' - locals will know you're a tourist! Order tagliatelle al rag√π instead
Bologna is THE food capital of Italy, not just a food destination - it earned 'La Grassa' for good reason
Hand-rolled pasta is the standard here - you'll see sfoglinas (pasta makers) rolling sheets in restaurant windows
Portions of couscous and pasta dishes are very large - come hungry!
The 62km of UNESCO-listed porticos provide covered walkways throughout the city, including the famous 3.8km Portico di San Luca
Osteria dell'Orsa is famous for vegetarian-friendly options (rare in meat-heavy Bologna)
Osteria del Sole (since 1465) is budget-friendly BYO - bring your own food, they pour the wine
Best time to visit: March-May or September-October for 15-22¬∞C weather perfect for portico strolls
